title: 106_s2712
content: The "Reports Consolidation Act of 2000" may be cited as the short title for this Act. The findings and purposes are outlined in Section 2. The "Reports Consolidation Act of 2000" aims to consolidate financial and performance management reports to improve efficiency and coordination, provide more useful information to Congress, the President, and the public, enhance the quality of agency information, and streamline reporting requirements. The "Reports Consolidation Act of 2000" aims to consolidate financial and performance management reports to improve efficiency and coordination among agencies. The "Reports Consolidation Act of 2000" amends Chapter 35 of title 31, United States Code by adding a section on reports consolidation. The "Reports Consolidation Act of 2000" allows executive agencies to adjust the frequency and due dates of statutorily required reports with the approval of the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. These reports can be consolidated into an annual report to be submitted to the President, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, and Congress within 150 days after the end of the agency's fiscal year. This includes various agency-specific reports and other statutorily required reports. The "Reports Consolidation Act of 2000" allows executive agencies to adjust the frequency and due dates of statutorily required reports. These reports can be consolidated into an annual report submitted to the President and Congress. The report may include other required reports if deemed useful by the agency head and after consulting relevant congressional committees. The report must incorporate the agency's program performance report or provide a summary of key performance goals achieved. The "Reports Consolidation Act of 2000" allows executive agencies to adjust the frequency and due dates of statutorily required reports. A report under subsection (a) should include a statement from the agency's inspector general summarizing the most serious management and performance challenges, and an assessment by the agency head on the completeness and reliability of performance and financial data used in the report. The agency head can comment on the inspector general's statement but cannot modify it. The "Reports Consolidation Act of 2000" allows executive agencies to submit consolidated reports within 180 days after the end of the fiscal year for 2000 and 2001. Amendments are made to sections 3515 and 3521 of title 31, United States Code, relating to audited financial statements. Additionally, amendments are made to program performance reports under section 1116(a) of title 31. The "Reports Consolidation Act of 2000" allows agencies to submit reports within 180 days after the fiscal year for 2000 and 2001. Amendments are made to program performance reports under section 1116(a) of title 31, United States Code. The agency can take actions to resolve inadequacies in program performance reports as required by the Reports Consolidation Act of 2000.
